highlights.text: To Indigenous people themselves, though, these developments mark a decisive moment in the evolution of our sovereignty in this country. The fact is, Canadians aren‚Äôt used to seeing Indigenous people occupy places that are socially, economically or geographically valuable, like SenÃì√°·∏µw. After decades of marginalization, our absence seems natural, our presence somehow unnatural. Something like SenÃì√°·∏µw is remarkable not just in terms of its scale and economic value (expected to generate billions in revenue for the Squamish Nation). It‚Äôs remarkable because it‚Äôs a restoration of our authority and presence in the heart of a Canadian city.

bookmarks.title: The Golden Age of American Jews Is Ending

highlights.text: Among the brutal epiphanies of October 7 was this: A disconcertingly large number of Israel‚Äôs critics on the left did not share that vision of peaceful coexistence, or believe Jews had a right to a nation of their own.

The anti-Zionism that has flourished on the left in recent years doesn‚Äôt stop with calls for an end to the occupation of the West Bank. It espouses a blithe desire to eliminate the world‚Äôs only Jewish-majority nation, valorizes the homicidal campaign against its existence, and seeks to hold members of the Jewish diaspora to account for the sins of a country they don‚Äôt live in and for a government they didn‚Äôt elect.

They call themselves ‚Äúeffective accelerationists,‚Äù or e/accs (pronounced ‚Äúe-acks‚Äù), and they believe A.I. will usher in a utopian future‚Äîinterstellar travel, the end of disease‚Äîas long as the worriers get out of the way.

highlights.text: Because a lot of the people who identify with Friedrich‚Äôs argument are self-described socialists, it‚Äôs somewhat ironic that this schema doesn‚Äôt make sense when you start digging into the interests of the relevant actors. I‚Äôm just a bourgeois shitlib, so far be it from me to accuse people of being insufficiently Marxist; but I do think the conversation around class and YIMBYism could use fewer vibes and a little more dialectical materialism.
More homebuilding is inherently redistributive: by driving down rents, it effectively moves wealth from rentiers to renters.

bookmarks.title: YIMBYism can liberate us from anti-capitalism
COVID Still Makes Everybody a Little Bit Crazy

highlights.text: I see this suggestion all the time, that the immunocompromised could be living lives of freedom and confidence if the rest of us committed to (generally vague) additional Covid measures. But these claims seem both insufficiently specific about what behaviors are demanded of the rest of us and insufficiently supported in terms of providing responsible scientific evidence to prove their efficacy.

But given the extravagant level of safety many people demand from Covid, I doubt most would return to anything like ordinary life. Indeed, it has always seemed plain to me that there are some people who do not want to return to ordinary life and thus are Covid extremists, not the other way around

nonisolated keyword

bookmarks.title: Sendable and @Sendable closures explained with code examples

highlights.text: Sendable protocol and closure
whether the public API of the passed values passed thread-safe to the compiler
no public mutators
internal locking system is in place
The class does not conform because it is a reference type and therefore mutable from other concurrent domains.
immutable classes
classes with internal locking mechanisms
@unchecked attribute
class is thread-safe due to internal locking mechanisms
Sendable protocol conformance must happen within the same source file to ensure that the compiler checks all visible members for thread safety.
the compiler can‚Äôt apply Sendable conformance outside of the source file as it has no visibility of the title property, even though the title is using a Sendable type String.
Since the class is non-final, we can‚Äôt conform to Sendable as we‚Äôre unsure whether other classes will inherit from User with non-Sendable members.
this does require us to ensure it‚Äôs always thread-safe whenever we inherit from User
functions can‚Äôt conform to protocols, so Swift introduced the @Sendable attribute
we will tell the compiler that he doesn‚Äôt need extra synchronization as all captured values in the closure are thread-safe
Minimal: The compiler will only diagnose instances explicitly marked with Sendable conformance
Targeted: Enforces Sendable constraints and performs actor-isolation checking
Complete: Matches the intended Swift 6 semantics to check and eliminate data races

bookmarks.title: Concurrent vs Serial DispatchQueue: Concurrency in Swift explained

highlights.text: A DispatchQueue
abstraction layer on top of the GCD queue that allows you to perform tasks asynchronously and concurrently
serial Dispatch Queue
one task at the time.
DispatchQueue defaults to a serial queue
A concurrent queue
execute multiple tasks at the same time
Tasks will always start in the order they‚Äôre added but they can finish in a different order
Tasks will run on distinct threads that are managed by the dispatch queue.
barrier
perform multiple tasks at the same time while still preventing data races
A data race can occur
multiple threads access the same memory without synchronization and at least one access is a write
Adding new messages to the array is done using the barrier flag which blocks new reads until the write is finished.
You can see a barrier as a task that gets in the way of parallel tasks and, for a moment, makes a concurrent queue a serial queue.
synchronously
asynchronously
block the calling thread until the task is finished
directly return on the calling thread without blocking
As the main thread is used for UI updates it‚Äôs important to be conscious when executing tasks on this queue.
creating threads comes with a cost and you should, therefore, avoid excessive thread creation.

bookmarks.title: Where will Swift Concurrency run your function?

highlights.text: The async keyword
the function may suspend its execution to switch threads
The await keyword
calling thread to wait while an async function performs its job
Main Thread
Cooperative Thread Pool.
non-async functions run as part of the calling thread
runs your function on the Cooperative Thread Pool whenever your function is async
It doesn‚Äôt matter where you call foo or boo functions. They will always run on the main thread because the Store type is isolated to the global @MainActor.
SwiftUI views are not isolated to any actor. Only the body property of the View protocol is isolated to the main actor.
The foo function is async, and Swift runs it in the cooperative thread pool. The boo function is not async, and Swift will run it on the calling thread.
